description:
Charles Translator for Ukraine is a free Czech-Ukrainian online translation service available for public at \url{https://translator.cuni.cz} and as an Android app. It was developed at Charles University in March 2022 to help refugees from Ukraine by narrowing the communication gap between them and other people in the Czech Republic. It is based on Transformer and Block Backtranslation \citep{popel-et-al:2020}.

}

description:
Our submission is a result of applying a novel n-best list reranking and modification method on translation
candidates produced by two other competing systems, CUNI-Transformer and CUNI-DocTransformer.
Our method uses a genetic algorithm and MBR decoding to search for optimal translation under a given
metric (in our case, a weighted combination of ChrF, BLEU, COMET22-DA, and COMET22-QE-DA).
name: CUNI-GA
publication_url: Miroslav Hrabal, Josef Jon, Martin Popel, Ondřej Bojar: CUNI at WMT24 General Translation Task: Mistral, (Q)LoRA, CPO and Model Merging

description:
CUNI-MH constrained submission is Mistral 7B v0.1 fine-tuned using PEFT methods for en->cs translation in three stages:

1. Supervised fine-tuning (SFT) using 4-bit QLoRA
2. Contrastive Preference Optimization (CPO) \cite{xu2024contrastivepreferenceoptimizationpushing} using LoRA 
3. Checkpoint merging

The data used for SFT is the authentic part of Czeng2.0. To create data set for CPO, we randomly sample around 40k documents from Czeng2.0 and use our partially trained model from SFT stage and our constrained model from previous years, CUNI-DocTransformer, to generate additional translations. We then use wmt20-comet-qe-da model to rank the translations and the reference.

@misc{xu2024contrastivepreferenceoptimizationpushing,
      title={Contrastive Preference Optimization: Pushing the Boundaries of LLM Performance in Machine Translation}, 
      author={Haoran Xu and Amr Sharaf and Yunmo Chen and Weiting Tan and Lingfeng Shen and Benjamin Van Durme and Kenton Murray and Young Jin Kim},
      year={2024},

}
name: CUNI-MH
publication_url: CUNI at WMT24 General Translation Task: Mistral, (Q)LoRA, CPO and Model Merging

description: The system is a speech translation system with audio prompting, which is then adapted to text-only translation. The speech translation system consists of a HuBERT with CTC collapsing module for extracting the audio feature, then such feature is fed to an LLM in order to perform both ASR and translation at the same time.
name: CUNI-NL
publication_url: WMT24

description:
The English$\leftrightarrow$Czech sentence-level models are exactly the same as submitted in WMT20 \citep{popel-2020-cuni}. The Ukrainian$\leftrightarrow$Czech models are very similar, also trained with Block Backtranslation. The Czech$\rightarrow$Ukrainian system uses in addition special preprocessing (romanization of the Ukrainian side and a vocabulary-based inline casing on both sides).

description: This paper details the submission by Global Tone Communication Co., Ltd. and Dalian University of Technology for the WMT24 shared general Machine Translation (MT) task at the Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing (EMNLP). Our participation covers two language pairs: English to Japanese and Japanese to Chinese. Our systems are developed without specific constraints or requirements, allowing for extensive exploration in machine translation. We prioritize back-translation, leverage multilingual translation models, and employ fine-tuning strategies to enhance performance. Furthermore, we integrate both human-generated and machine-generated data to fine-tune our models, resulting in more accurate translations. The automatic evaluation results indicate that our system ranks first in terms of BLEU score for Japanese to Chinese.
name: DLUT_GTCOM
publication_url: DLUT and GTCOM's Machine Translation Systems for WMT24

description: The Helsinki-NLP submitted four multilingual models, each utilizing different methodologies. The team collected additional data from Wikipedia and online dictionaries to supplement the provided datasets. Their approaches included fine-tuning a pre-existing OPUS-MT model and applying sequence-level distillation, by leveraging both neural and rule-based machine translation outputs. For submission, they experimented with ensembling methods. Their models were evaluated for both translation quality and efficiency, resulting in a diverse set of submissions that balance accuracy and speed. The Helsinki-NLP team's contributions, including their code and data, are publicly available for further research and development.
name: helsinki-nlp

primary_submissions.competition: WMT24: Translation into Low-Resource Languages of Spain

WMT24: Translation into Low-Resource Languages of Spain

publication_url: WMT24

description: This paper presents the submission of Huawei Translate Services Center (HW-TSC) to the WMT24 general machine translation (MT) shared task, where we participate in the English to Chinese (en→zh) language pair. Similar to last year, we use training strategies such as regularized dropout, bidirectional training, data diversification, forward translation, back translation, alternated training, curriculum learning, and transductive ensemble learning to train the NMT model based on the deep Transformer-big architecture. The difference is that we also use monolingual continuation training, supervised fine-tuning, and contrastive preference learning to train the Llama2-13B based LLM model. By using MBR decoding to select the final translation from multiple hypotheses for NMT and LLM systems, our submission receives competitive results in the final evaluation.
name: HW-TSC

description: IKUN-C is based on the Mistral-7B-v0.3. We continuously pre-train it in 11 languages mainly with the recent 10 years News Crawl data. After the pretraining, we finetuned it on all 11 language directions data which is from the test and dev set of WMT16-23, NTREX, dev and devtest of Flores.
name: IKUN-C

description: IOL Research submission is based on a large language model (LLM) with 20 billion parameters, which is a scaled-up variant of Qwen1.5-14B, in accordance with the SOLAR approach. Initially, we conducted continued pretraining on the scaled-up model using CC-Aligned data and monolingual data from ten languages covering all translation directions to improve multilingual knowledge. Consider high quality parallel data is difficult to obtain, we leveraged synthetic data generated by the c4ai-command-r-plus and Qwen1.5-110B-Chat instruction models for supervised fine-tuning. For the creation of synthetic data, we employed a variety of techniques, including forward translation, back translation, and auto post-editing. Moreover, we integrated this synthetic data with open-source document parallel data to augment our capability in translating long-form text. Lastly, we also tried ensemble learning to further improve translation quality.
name: IOL_Research
publication_url: IOL Research Machine Translation Systems for WMT24 General Machine Translation Shared Task

description: The MSLC (Metric Score Landscape Challenge) submissions for English--German, English--Spanish, and Japanese--Chinese are constrained systems built using Transformer models for the purpose of better evaluating metric performance in the WMT24 Metrics Task. All are sentence-level models that handle paragraph- or document-level translation by performing sentence splitting, translation, and then recombining the translated sentences. The English--German model is the same model described in \citep{lo-etal-2023-metric}. The English--Spanish model uses language identification for training data filtering. The Japanese--Chinese model incorporates additional preprocessing and postprocessing.
name: MSLC
publication_url: Samuel Larkin, Chi-kiu Lo, Rebecca Knowles; MSLC24 Submissions to the General Machine Translation Task

description:
The TAN-IBE team, consisting of participants from the project \emph{TAN-IBE: Neural Machine Translation for the Romance Languages of the Iberian Peninsula}, has developed systems for all language pairs in the task: Spanish-Asturian, Spanish-Aragonese, and Spanish-Aranese. The team submitted entries for both constrained and open categories.

The main concern of the team was not only the lack of resources for these language pairs but also the poor quality of the available resources. To address these issues, we decided to:

\begin{itemize}
\item Clean the existing parallel corpora using a tool developed during the project that rechecks the language of the segments and calculates the cosine similarity between source and target segments.
\item Create parallel corpora from Wikipedia for all three language pairs.
\item Experiment with the use of back-translated corpora.
\item Experiment with the use of multilingual systems.
\end{itemize}

For the constrained submission, we present systems using:

\begin{itemize}
\item {\bf spa-ast}: Cleaned NLLB corpus + 13M synthetic data using Apertium.
\item {\bf spa-arg}: Cleaned WikiMatrix + 13M synthetic data using Apertium.
\item {\bf spa-oci_aran}: PILAR corpus data back-translated using Apertium + 13M synthetic data using Apertium.
\end{itemize}
name: TAN-IBE

primary_submissions.competition: WMT24: Translation into Low-Resource Languages of Spain

description: We participated in the constrained track for English-Japanese and Japanese-Chinese translations at the WMT 2024 General Machine Translation Task. Our approach was to generate a large number of sentence-level translation candidates and select the most probable translation using minimum Bayes risk (MBR) decoding and document-level large language model (LLM) re-ranking. We first generated hundreds of translation candidates from multiple translation models and retained the top 30 candidates using MBR decoding. In addition, we continually pre-trained LLMs on the target language corpora to leverage document-level information. We utilized LLMs to select the most probable sentence sequentially in context from the beginning of the document.
name: Team J
publication_url: Document-level Translation with LLM Reranking: Team-J at WMT 2024 General Translation Task

description: This paper describes the Transducens team's contribution to the WMT24 Shared Task:  Translation into Low Resource Languages of Spain. The task focuses on translation from Spanish into Aragonese, Aranese and Asturian. We used parallel and monolingual data to fine-tune NLLB and explore the use of synthetic corpora and also transfer learning between related languages such as Catalan, Galician and Valencian to build an n-n multilingual Neural Machine Translation model focused on the Romance languages of Spain.
name: Transducens

description: Hyper-SNMT represents a cutting-edge approach in the field of machine translation. Hyper-SNMT addresses this limitation by embedding sentences in a hyperbolic space, where distances naturally reflect language hierarchy and dependencies. This novel embedding space enables the model to achieve more accurate translations, especially for languages ​​with complex grammatical structures and rich morphology. Both speed and accuracy are significantly improved compared to existing models. This paper provides a comprehensive overview of the theoretical foundations, implementation details, and empirical results of Hyper-SNMT, highlighting its potential to revolutionize the field of neural machine translation.
name: TranssionMT
publication_url: Zebiao Zhou, Xiangxun Zhu, Xiaowei Ji, Li Yang, Fengjie Zhu, Tuanwei Shi: TranssionMT at Translation Task

description: The system presented by the TSU HITs team is a discrete diffusion approach with absorbing diffusion based on the XLM-RoBERTa-Large model. The main improvement is to more accurately determine the length of the output sequence by using a separate length prediction model, the target of which is not the length itself in its pure form, but the normalized ratio of the lengths of the input and output sequences. It is demonstrated that using the length of the input sequence in the process of determining the length of the output sequence allows to obtain more accurate (close to the reference) results, and a more accurate prediction of the length eventually leads to better diffusive generation. In comparison with earlier solutions, where the classification approach is used, in the TSU HITs system, the length predictor solves the regression problem. It is assumed that these methods can improve another diffusion-based machine translation architectures too.
name: TSU HITs
publication_url: Vladimir Mynka, Nikolay Mikhaylovskiy: Predicting the Length of the Output Sequence for Diffusion-Based Machine Translation Methods (WMT24)

description: Unbabel-IST submission is a new version of Tower LLM (https://arxiv.org/pdf/2402.17733) combined with Quality Aware decoding~\cite{fernandes-etal-2022-quality}. The new model has 70B parameters and supports 15 languages. The biggest improvements come from a new recipe to do Continued-pretraining (CPT) and Instruction Tuning (IT). The CPT mixes monolingual and parallel data while the IT uses a mix of different tasks ranging from "general-purpose" LLM instruction following tasks to MT specific tasks like Document-level MT, sentence-level MT, APE, etc.
name: Unbabel-Tower70B
publication_url: Tower-v2: Unbabel-IST 2024 Submission for the General MT Shared Task

description: This paper describes the UvA-MT’s submission to the WMT 2024 shared task on general machine translation. We participate in the constraint tracks in three directions: English → Chinese, English → Japanese, and Japanese → Chinese. We began by training conventional machine translation baseline systems from scratch, using strategies such as Quality Estimation (QE) data filtering and task-oriented fine-tuning. We also explored the use of Large Language Models to enhance MT outputs through post-editing. Additionally, we fine-tuned Llama-2 with high-quality QE data. While Llama-2 performed accurately on the Flores benchmark, it produced off-target predictions on the WMT-24 test set, indicating a possible data leakage from Flores into Llama-2.
name: UvA-MT
publication_url: Shaomu Tan, Di Wu, David Stap, Seth Aycock, Christof Monz: UvA-MT’s Participation in the WMT24 General Translation Shared Task
